Many Australians are concerned about the welfare of the animals we eat, but we can struggle to find welfare-friendly products that come from animals that have had optimal welfare.
 
  That’s because animal-based products come with a barrage of labels, claims or certifications, such as organic, cage-free, free-range, vegetarian-fed, humane or humanely raised.
 
  In Australia, legislation does not require producers to adequately disclose information about farm production methods. So, while many producers and retailers want to support best practice in the production and supply of animal-based foods, the challenges of labelling are rendering the intentions of consumers and suppliers meaningless.
 
  Kinder Food Finder will help you decipher these accreditations by providing ratings of Avoid, Good, or Best that tell you all you need to know regarding the animal welfare conditions behind them. We reduce the confusion and give you the power to make kinder choices.
\u0020\u0020Kinder Food Finder was created by students at the University of Sydney.
\u0020\u0020Our ratings are based on animal welfare criteria that were created by students and staff at the University of Sydney.
Where do we get our information?

\u0020\u0020Our ratings are based on the information provided by independent, third party accreditations, such as RSPCA Approved Farming Scheme, Humane Choice, and Australian Certified Organic, to name a few.\n \n\u0020\u0020Third-party accreditations are the most transparent animal welfare labels on the market. When a product is not covered by an independent accreditation, we cannot verify the animal welfare conditions behind the product.
Why should you use Kinder Food Finder?

\u0020\u0020We know people care about the animal welfare conditions of the food they eat and they want to find animal-based products that have been produced more humanely. However, sometimes it’s too hard for people to make good food choices. Animal-based products come with so many confusing labels, claims or certifications on products at the supermarket, and there simply isn’t time for most of us to do in-depth research on every item of food we buy.\n \n\u0020\u0020We decipher these accreditations for you by providing ratings of Avoid, Good, or Best, that tell you all you need to know regarding the animal welfare conditions behind them.
Why did you give a rating of Good to an accreditation that allows beak trimming?

\u0020\u0020Beak-trimming is the partial removal of a layer hen\'s beak and it is done to avoid injuries from hens pecking each other, sometimes to death. Unfortunately, feather pecking can occur in any layer hen housing system, especially non-cage systems. Therefore, when there is the risk of feather pecking and potential death to many hens, we believe beak-trimming is necessary to prevent or control it.
Why did you give a rating of Good to an accreditation that doesn’t allow outdoor access?
\u0020\u0020We believe an enhanced, well-managed indoor system can achieve good welfare for farmed animals.
In which countries is Kinder Food Finder available?
\u0020\u0020Currently, it is available only in Australia. We’d love to expand globally in the future.
Will we rate other animal-based products?

\u0020\u0020The welfare issues we address are non-exhaustive and limited to the most widespread and prevalent issues that pose the greatest threat to the welfare of production animals.\n \n\u0020\u0020Currently, we cover only the production of eggs, chicken and pig products. The decision to focus on these products was made because of the seriousness and prevalence of welfare issues facing laying hens, broilers (meat chickens) and pigs. We plan to expand to include other animal production systems in later versions.
\u0020\u0020Get in touch by emailing us as kinder.foodfinder@gmail.com

• Beak-trimming is the partial removal of a layer hen's beak done to avoid injuries from hens pecking each other, sometimes to death. (RSPCA, FREPA and Egg Corp Assured Scheme allow this procedure) 

• Enrichment refers to features of an environment that improve animals' wellbeing by providing an opportunity to carry out natural behaviours 

• On-farm assessment refers to whether the accreditation visits the farm to ensure they meet the necessary standards 

• Fast-growing breeds refers to the use of chickens bred to grow at unnaturally fast rates (upwards of three times their natural rate). These fast-growing chicken breeds represent the majority of chickens raised for meat in Australia, and result in chickens being killed before reaching maturity, often at around 5-7 weeks of age and up to 8-10 weeks in organic system (broiler chickens' natural lifespan is up to 8 years) 

• A sow stall is a highly confining type of housing used for pregnant pigs in which the sow (female pig) is unable to turn around 

• A farrowing crate is a highly confining type of housing in which the sow is unable to turn around and in which she is confined for approximately 4 weeks to give birth and suckle her piglets 

• Tail-docking is the removal of a portion of a piglet's tail 

• Teeth-clipping is the cutting or clipping of a piglet's canine teeth 

• Weaning is when piglets are taken from their mothers and receive nourishment from other food sources other than milk
